p: Early cases of MERS in Saudi Arabia in 2012; ( 37) had contact with animals, in particular with dromedary camels ( Figure 1B). Molecular and serological data indicated the presence of MERS viruses in dromedaries with high sequence similarities (>99%) to human MERS-CoV ( 38), and antibodies in camels could be traced back to the eighties ( 31, 39). More molecular data support that human and camel MERS-CoV isolates belong to the same coronavirus species, and that MERS-CoV originated from the bat gene pool ( 31). Ancestor analysis suggests that MERS-CoV could have spilled from bats to camels some 30 years ago in Africa, and it was subsequently introduced in the Arabian Peninsula by importing camels from the African continent ( 40).
